title: How to Make Frozen Pizza Better

steps.headline: Add fresh ingredients to recreate your favorite classic pizza recipes.
steps.description: There are lots of different recipes for pizza, and all of them are delicious! Pick your favorite and get the ingredients that aren't already on your frozen pizza so that you can add them. Put the toppings on your frozen pizza before you put it in the oven so everything cooks evenly. Go Hawaiian-style with some tasty ham and some pineapple! Use a frozen cheese pizza and add some fresh tomatoes and basil for a quick Margherita pizza. Create a buffalo chicken pizza by adding grilled chicken breast, hot sauce, and ranch.

steps.headline: Layer on mozzarella or parmesan for extra cheesy goodness.
steps.description: Even though your frozen pizza already has cheese on it, a little more couldn’t hurt! Plus, using fresh mozzarella that will bubble as the pizza cooks will just make everything better. Slice some freshwater mozzarella and arrange it on top of the pizza. You can add different cheeses to make a more complex flavor as well. For example, slices of gouda or asiago can add some sharpness to the pizza. If you don’t have any freshwater mozzarella, shredded cheese works great, too! If you’re a vegan or you have a dairy allergy, use a plant-based vegan cheese to add some gooey goodness to your pizza!

steps.headline: Cut up fresh vegetables and place them on the pizza.
steps.description: Fresh tomatoes, onions, jalapenos, or whatever vegetables you enjoy will greatly enhance your frozen pizza experience. Before you put your pizza in the oven, slice up some fresh ingredients and arrange them evenly on top of your pizza. Fresh vegetables will cook with the pizza to change the texture and add flavor to the frozen pizza.

steps.headline: Slice some fresh sausage, pepperoni, or chorizo for a meat lover’s pizza.
steps.description: Pepperoni and sausage are classic ingredients for a tasty, meaty pizza. Mexican chorizo is a spicy sausage that adds a ton of flavor to a frozen pizza. Cut up some chunks of meat and put them on top of your pizza before you cook it for a delicious addition. Cut up chunks of sausage about ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) thick.Tip: Use a spicy chorizo to add some heat to your frozen pizza if you prefer.

steps.headline: Sprinkle some classic pizza seasonings to add extra flavor.
steps.description: Add some Italian seasonings like oregano, garlic, and basil on top of the pizza to bring out the flavor. You can also add your own flavors by using spicy seasonings like cayenne or red pepper flakes. Sprinkle a small amount on top of the pizza so you don’t overwhelm it with a single seasoning. If you don’t have fresh seasonings, dried or powdered versions work as well. Don’t add any extra salt. The frozen pizza will have plenty of it.

steps.headline: Add a bunch of greens on top of the pizza when it’s done.
steps.description: When you take the pizza out of the oven, put some fresh arugula or a mesclun mix on top of it to add a fresh crunch to it. You can use any greens that you want, just pile them high on the pie when it’s finished cooking and you can have pizza and salad at the same time! Spinach, kale, and even shredded cabbage can add another level to the pizza’s flavor profile and texture.

steps.headline: Drizzle some olive oil on top when you take it out of the oven.
steps.description: Use high-quality olive oil to add the last touches of deliciousness to your frozen pizza. As soon as the pizza is done, pull it out of the oven and drizzle some of the oil on top of it. You could also drizzle a little bit of honey on top of the pizza to add some sweetness to the saltiness.

steps.headline: Choose a good quality frozen pizza for the best results.
steps.description: It’s difficult to enhance a frozen pizza that starts out as poor quality. When you’re in the frozen section, opt for one of the higher-end frozen pizzas. Your tastebuds will thank you for it. You can find good quality frozen pizza at your local grocery store. Better quality frozen pizzas usually range from $10 to $15. You can still doctor up any frozen pizza to make it better than it would be on its own!

steps.headline: Defrost the pizza and set the oven to 550 °F (288 °C).
steps.description: Take the pizza out of its box and wrapping and let it sit on the counter for an hour or so, until it’s fully defrosted. To replicate a real pizza oven, turn up the temperature to a high temperature, and allow the oven to fully preheat. Your frozen pizza will have a better crust and will be much more like a pizza from a pizza oven.

steps.headline: Place the pizza directly on the lowest oven rack.
steps.description: To get the best crust and the bubbliest cheese, skip the baking pan and place the pizza directly onto the oven rack. Use the lowest oven rack for better convection and circulation around the pizza. Slide out the rack and place the pizza onto it so you don’t burn yourself and the toppings don’t shift around.Tip: If you have a pizza stone or a large cast-iron skillet, place the pizza on them on the lowest rack in the oven. They’ll help to replicate the surface of a real wood-fired pizza oven.

steps.headline: Bake the pizza for 5 to 8 minutes.
steps.description: The high temperature of the oven and the fact that the pizza is defrosted means it will cook pretty quickly. Keep an eye on it and pull it out of the oven whenever the crust is as crispy as you want it to be. Let the pizza cook for at least 5 minutes so all of the ingredients are heated properly. Be careful not to cook the pizza past 10 minutes or it could burn.

steps.headline: Brush the crust with garlic butter 2 minutes before it’s done.
steps.description: Melt 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of butter in a bowl, mince 2 cloves of garlic, and whisk them together to combine them. Use a pastry brush to coat the crust of the pizza 2 minutes before it’s finished cooking to add extra flavor and to make the crust golden brown and crispy. If you don’t have a pastry brush, drizzle the garlic butter over the crust with a spoon.
